of letters aida wrote but did not send. how these letters came into John Berger 's possession, he writes," must remain, for the moment, a secret, for the explanation would endanger other parties. thus, the author invites us into his fictional world as accomplices, comrades and co-conspirators. the rest of the book belongs to John Berger 's letter-writing protagonist, aida. from the first letter to the last, the force of aida's desire for her beloved xavier is what gives this book its shape and meaning. a visceral and immediate longing seeps into every salutation- mi gaupo, mi soplete, my kanadim, hayati, ya nour- every memory, every anecdote of daily life. the ephemeral is not the opposite of the eternal, "she writes." the opposite of the eternal is the forgotten.
